Wonderfull peacefull place in the middle of Bangkok. We went to Bangkok last year, but didn't go to Lumpini Park.This year we had the time to go here, and my goodness it is amazing.We went in the morning before it's too hot (though it was already quite hot), and it was just a great experience. It's nice and peacefull, which is difficult to find in a town as Bangkok. My hubby did in particular find the water monitors very interesting. We saw one of the bigger ones swimming just at the bridge, so we got a look at how big they are.

Best public park in Bangkok!. Biggest public park in Bangkok and most beautiful! At morning old people came to park to run, bike, join yoga or other open air activity. I saw few gyms, many benches to relax and special areas with tables and umbrellas to have lunch and shelter from rain. You may rent boats or catamaran (40 bat for 30 min / 80bat for 1 hour). Many varans living in park (from half meter till 1.5 meter length), turtles, cats, birds. In water you may find many fishes - bring some food to feed them and have fun! Perfect place to relax on the green grass or observe life of "wild life" - you may be it 1 meter from varan or even closer, but don't forget what they can bite. Many trees, flowers, good road condition. Parking and food market outside, small food court inside park. Closed at 9PM.
Great place to see Thai way of life. Everything is there from food stalls on certain side of the park, to areas for resting and picnicking, to kids playground. This is the BKK's Central Park.

Lumpini Park. Brilliant it must be visited on a Sunday morning early, everyone walks round the paths talking to complete strangers you can actually here the hum of voices from some distance away. Fascinating place.

Lumpini is such a great place. Its so wonderful seeing so many people of all aged groups exercising every morning and evening. Beautifully kept grounds, lovely big lake...great place to relax, walk and unwind.

Best in the morning to see local life. The equivalent of New York's Central Park, the place is best visited from 5:00 am to 9:00 am when people from all walks of life are out exercising and engaging in many different activities, from running to dancing and anything else in between. It is a good place to take a look at local life, and get a feel for how Bangkokians get out and about before the heat of the day hits. There is plenty of food stalls open around the park, where you can sample some local cuisine as well. The afternoon is not recommended, because it is simply too hot. It is a bit scary at night, so stay away then..There are also some paddle and rowboats available for rent in 30 minute blocks, if that interests you.

A beautiful escape in the middle of a busy city!. The park was right opposite the hotel where I was staying... in fact I managed to get a room with a lovely view of the greenery.... Its a great place to go for your morning walk or jog... also a good place to sit around , slow down and people watch .... you can also spot colorful birds and lizards. If you get here in the morning you can also catch folks practicing Tai Chi ... there are stalls selling food too...

Bangkok Relaxation for Free!. As a resident of a huge city with no parks, visiting this st in Bangkok was cathartic. The park includes exercise equipment, lots of shady spots, and, if you are there on Sunday at 6, free aerobics. Feed the fish, observe the monitor lizards swim through the river, and people watch.

Peace and quite in a mad city!. Located across the road from Dusit Thani hotel so it was just crossing the road for us to visit the park. It is huge and you get a sense of its size if you take a ride round it. It is a bit of peace and quiet in this mad and bustling city. There are some stalls selling food and bits and bobs. Lots of loacls around especially in the evening.

Good for people living in Bangkok. For tourist a visit to this park is not recommended. For people living in Bangkok it's a good place to visit to spend some quality peaceful time with family. The boat ride is fun too.

A fresh breathing in the heart of Bankok. A very quiet green park to walk and relax in the heart of Bangkok! To recover of the very busy Bangkok you can find a lovely park to walk, watch birds and lizards. Go there also for a picnic or just to relax with your girl/boy friend or with your kids, or even alone to be in peace.

Park with lots of animals. Big park. We went there on a thursday and everything was closed. It made it look a bit run down. In the park we so lots of people sleeping in the pavilions.In the park you see lots of birds and Iguanas.

Go to see the Monitor Lizards!. How to get there: We took the BTS Skytrain to the Sala Daeng stop and exited side 4. We walked east along Silom Road (toward the BTS Ratchadamri stop) and took a right on Rama 4 road. The park will be right on the corner on your left hand side. If you don’t know how to use the BTS, google “How to use the BTS skytrain in Bangkok with map route and station details.”Really we went to see the Monitor Lizards. There are a lot of them around. They are about as big as an alligator and they have long tongues. There were a couple of stand set up at the entrance near Silom and Rama 4 roads. They were selling food, mostly fruits. The park was beautiful. The was a lot of green grass, fountains, bridges, ponds and flowers.There was a bathroom in the park with a funny sign. Do not wash your feet (in the sink!) On the far end near Witthayu (Wireless) Road there was another even more beautiful entrance. We walked along this road and looked at multiple embassies. They are interesting to look at, too.We hopped back on the BTS when Wireless ran into Pholenchit Road. To the right was the PhloenChit stop and to the left was ChitLom. They were close to one another.

Great park for relaxation. It's not as big as New York's Central Park, but this is a nice park in the center of Bangkok. One lap of walking would take about 30 minutes (2km). This is a safe place to run, jog, or walk as there is quite a lot of well-manner people who look out for each other.

Green Lung of Bangkok. Large park in the center of Bangkok. Full of interesting characters and wildlife (check out the water monitor lizards the size of Komodo Dragons!)Just don't feed the pigeons - my Missus did and was nearly arrested by a rude and overbearing park cop. Also, try crossing the orad to get to the park with extreme caution!

Peace & Tranquility. Really enjoyed my visit to Lumphini Park. Bangkok is usually crowded and polluted so great to escape it at thei large park. There are lots of places to sit in the shade and enjoy the peace. The park itself is enormous and has flowers, a kids area and various wildlife stolling the place. It also has water sprinklers that give a quick shower if wanted. There wasnt many people around and it was nice to meet the few thai people who were there and very friendly.

See strange creatures. On a damp and overcast day in downtown Bangkok what better place to seek out strange creatures than th central Lumpini park.From white cranes to hundreds of bread eating fish and enormous lizard Take a ride on a duck in the lake .
Great Park. A nice park in the heart of Bangkok. Relaxing at the lake or strolling through the park is worth a visit

Stroll in the Park. My husband and I went to Lumpini Park in the late morning during the middle of the week. There wasn't much activity at all during this time of day. It was a nice distance to walk/run. We had fun getting up close and personal with several Monitor lizards around the park. There were several and they were huge! The restrooms were clean and available. We bought some fish food and fed some koi. The MRT stop is close by. If you are in Bangkok for several days and would like a place to walk around outside, this would be a great choice.

Away from the hustle and bustle but still within the city. Probably one of my favorite place in Bangkok. It's just a regular park yea, but it's really clean, green, and surprisingly entertaining. (Monitor) lizards hanging from the trees, their babies in the nearby water, old locals doing Tai Chi, paddleboats, and maybe many more if we stayed the whole day. If you want to relax from the weariness of walking around the city, travelling solo or in group, you should see this place without necessarily spending.

Nice and quiet. A hide away in the big Mango. It is nice, quiet (for the most part) and a lot of vegetation without the need to leave the city. Many activities during the day and lots of jogging room.

Paddleboats and goannas. We visited the park mid day and went for a paddleboat trip on the lake. According to Lonely Planet there is more activity in early morning and later afternoon, which could be true because there wasn't a lot happening. It was OK to kill an hour or so until the snake demonstration started at the nearby snake farm.And yes, you can indeed find live goannas by the lakeside.

green city escape with paddle boats. We went to the park just to soak up some green after all the high rise.The park is not too big, and reasonably well maintained. It has public toilets at a fee of 2 baht.You can take the paddle boats out on the lake for 40 baht per 30 minutes.Bring your camera as some gigantic reptiles are in and around the water. and did I mention we ran into a turtle?Access via Si Lom metro or BTS Sala Deng

Good walking area. Good place to get away from the city for a bit. Nice place to walk and has some small lakes. It doesn't seem like a real park. Its mostly concrete and some grass, so you don't get the real park experience. Its still a good place to go.

Returning back to excellence. One of the better parks for relaxing, walking, jogging, around water to relax. Close to the Lumpini MRT. Expect it to return back to its former beauty before living area for demonstrators.

Time for some exercise!. I live very close to here and have spent many hours just walking around the park and taking in all the sights and sounds.A great way to stay fit as well .Good for the mind and body.

Relaxing. I go there to stay relax in the evening. Then you can have walk to nearby night market in the afternoon. If you go there by MRT, do not get off at Lumpini Station. Silom is much closer. If go by BTS use Sala Daeng.

Relax Time. This place is just...amazing!! I stayed at the Dusit Tani hotel right in front of Lumpini Park. Just the smell of the flowers in the lobby areas would leave you breathless. A peaceful place to meditate or just sit there and do nothing.
Nice respite from the hustle of Bangkok. We enjoyed a morning stroll through the park on our last day of touring. It was peaceful and a nice change of pace from driving around in a taxi or tuk-tuk.
Relatively fresh lung. It's not central park, but it's nice for a stroll as long as you stay out of the heat and go in the early or late hours of the day.

Green Oasis. Great park but it is a little run down. Needs new facilities and the ground needs to be repathed.
Nice place to go - but again hard to get there if u don't drive.
A garden in town. This garden is located in the center of BKK. There is a boat to rent, if you want to explore more. The garden is different from most of the garden in Beijing. The park is clean !!!

Amazing!. Lumpini park was one of the main highlights of my trip. It is a wonderful place in the heart of Bangkok, and the wildlife was incredible. The main attraction of the park are the water monitors that roam freely. There were some protests going on while I was there, but I never felt as though I was in danger.
Nice park in the center of Bangkok. Lumpini Park is a nice and large park to walk around. It is great in the morning and evening. It is a few BTS stations from Siam Paragon.
Nice for a stroll. Go in the eveining at about 6pm, nice and cool an is entertaining watching the locals doing their dance class.

Sun Rise. The park has a beauty '' easily surmountable '' by our European parks. But its charm grows to excess in the first hours of the morning. It needs to arrive very soon before rising sun to assist to a fantastic show. The early-morning gymnastics of an oriental people. Children, adults, young people and elderly. All involved in a magic dance that(a very elderly lady told me), helps the sun to rise on the city. If you think to arrive after the 7 AM, I recommend you to remain to sleep in the hotel. It is not worth of it.
Great place to relax or exercise. It's hot in the day, but at 5pm to 6pm it is the best time to relax or exercise at the Lumpini Park. Popular for both local and tourists.

Peace And Quite In The Middle Of Craziness. i couldn't believe how quiet it was in this park,within 5 mins of entering you could forget you were in one of the biggest and busiest cities in the world.they are water lizards roaming about,fish to feed,children's play area and some fantastic buildings to look at.just go here to chill out for a while,you will forget where you are for a short while.im glad i payed a visit to this park,hard to imagine how crazy the place must of been when the protests were moved into this park,it was so clean.

Beautiful. Its amazing that a park like this is in the middle of bangkok. Walked around the entire park and it looked amazing and this is only weeks after the protesters has been occupying it. I would recommend anyone saying in Bangkok for a length of time to check it out

A tranquility in a metropolis. A big park in the centre of the city - Very busy at weekends & on Thai holidays as the locals flock to this location - Kids can run about but watch out for the dragons, 3-4 foot lizards which roam wild - bring a blanket & lay on the grass along with the thousands of locals - Plenty here for Geocachers.
Great place for a break in the city. Beautiful park in the heart of Bangkok, very peaceful, large lakes, well maintained and a pleasure to walk though every day
Air. Good place if You are nearby and just drop for a park walk, jogging or breathing the air. But not so much worth to go there on purpode from far districts

An oasis in the city. I intended my visit to Lumpini Park to be an exercise outing. I did walk 5K (around the park twice) but SLOWLY as I was so taken in by may surroundings! I couldn't help but stop to for photos along the way. This park is a treasure of beautiful statues and sculptures as well as home to two outdoor gyms and a thriving population of monitor lizards. I was happy to find that between the hours of 10 a.m. and 3 p.m. you are allowed to bike or skate through the park. There are also plenty of vendors at the park gate to offer you refreshment. I fell in love with Lumpini Park for its reflection of Thai culture and refreshing break from the busy city.

Relaxing walk in the park. This park is serene and is spread over a large area and we had a relaxing walk in the park. The lake in the middle had the swan like peddling boats which we hired for an hour and just peddled around the lake. If you happen to be there in the evenings then you would be seeing large group of people exercising to music near the lake.

Simply amazing. First came across this place on Tripadvisor.com, then strongly wanted to visit and see it with my own eyes. Finally i got the chance yesterday and liked it very much. The park is huge, you can take a rest under the shades of coco trees , or by the water during the hot days of Bangkok. You can also ride a bike or come there for jogging. Simply beautiful park, thanks tripadvisor for showing me this spot
Peace and quiet. What a glorious way to unwind away from the hustle and bustle of everyday Bangkok. Take some time out to step back and relax.

Only natural place available in central of Bangkok. If you can not find out any place for your running. Do not forget this place, the garden is only one available in the central of Bangkok where is full of tree, roses, fresh environment. You may exercise your body, playground, running over there. No entrance ticket require.

Nice to see it being brought back to life. Great to see all the effort going into the park to bring it back to life following the protesters destroying many parts of it.It's worth a walk round as it's a but if peace and quiet in the busy hustle of the city
Busy Market. Well worth a visit for those odds and end, but watch out for pick pockets. The food is open air, with plenty to choose from.

Green spaces in the heart of Bangkok. Bangkok can be a daunting megalopolis, but one can find at lumpini Park a beautiful place to breathe fresh air and enjoy large and well maintained greenery. A favorite for joggers and walkers of all ages, it is a great place to shed the inevitable extra calories consumed in the numerous Bangkok restaurants!
Green Oasis. Huge Park. Lovely for a stroll to escape the noisy city.Lot's of trees to avoid the blazing sun. For me a must visit!
Very nice gardens. Very nice just to go and relax.... you tend to forget that you in the middle of Bangkok City... a good getaway from the hustle and bustle...

Skønt. great place in the middle of the bustling Bangkok. you can cycle up for a long walk around or go and take pictures and enjoy all the different trees and plants. around the stream is filled with a kind varandaer, Oversættelsewhich is basking in the sun, you can get up close and take pictures. a really good place that is worth to visit.

From Pagoda Dragons to Tai Chi. This park is a mix of many things- bicyclists, joggers, mass outside aerobics classes working out to the beat, tai chi, birds, ponds and pagoda dragons- to name a few. Many things to watch and do. The greenery offered refreshing shade in the heat of Bangkok.

Nice park.. Run down externally . This is nice for a walk.. Watch out for the lizards! Quite run down externally.. Not sure if its due to the recent protests or not. Nice to unwind for a bit but wouldn't come back.. A few monuments around. Not sure what all the fuss is about

what did I see?. mmmm this wasn't a great place but because its in the city and a well known famous park - I would not brag about it.therefore I will not say much . its a park ! a few monuments around the place but pretty run down externally and looks like the Bronx - sorry

A Park for All Seasons. Lumpini Park had been catering to the need of the Bangkok residence for ages. The park had evolved from generation to generation with different infra-structure added or deducted firm it. Whatever happened the park was always the refuge for the city residence especially for their daily exercise. Starting from its opening at 5:00 a.m. til its closing time, the place was frequented by all walk of life.Hence I would recommend tourist or visitor to visit the place and understanding the local residence in their activities within the park. I had visited the Stanley Park in Vancouver and the Central Park in New York. So much I learned and absorbed from meeting the local and non-local. Isn't this part of the beauty in tourism in connecting us in different countries with similar activities. I would recommend to visit the park between 6-8 a.m. and 5-7 p.m. Have a good walk and say hi to some local. You will be amazed the friendly response in return.

Excellent getaway from the Hustle and Bustle. Grab yourself a coffee or Iced tea, Grab your Book... and when Bangkok becomes to much for you..head to Lumpini Park.its a shame theres not more of these Gorgeous spaces around Bangkok, but for those not to far away, ti gives you the chance to unwind and centre yourself, before going back in for battle with the Amazing city of Bangkok

Sunday morning visit to the park. Lumpini Park on a Sunday morning is a delight. A variety of activities: Jogging or walking around the 2.5 km track, cycling, roller balding, all going in the same direction. Going with the flow is advisable as it makes life easier. On the various stretches of grass there are groups going through their yoga, Tai Chi and vedic chanting and it seems that you are welcome to join in most groups. There is of course the inevitable Thai Massage and variety of food vendors in and around the park. getting there early in the morning and doing a few laps of inner road and then enjoying some Thai Tea is highly recommended for those that enjoy this kind of thing. You will experience an aspect of Thai culture that is easy to miss if you are on the treadmill of the standard "Bangkok" tours. The water monitors (huge lizards) are natures garbage collectors, and part of the flora and fauna

No more protesters. Hourrah no more protesters. This is a very nice park jn the centre of bangkok. Really want to relaxed? Go to park Rama 9. Worth the effort. Bit this is the second best and it is easier to get there;)

Overall very nice but currently home of the protest camp. In fact it is a very nice park with even a very big varan living there, but at the moment I have to rate it poor becasue the protestors put up their camp there and blocking the complete park which is a pitty.
Pretty but a lot of litter. The lake is nice and we did some paddle boats, but it is a shame there is so much litter in the park. Some huge lizards!

Beautiful, serene park. While, I wouldn't tell someone on a short trip to Bangkok that they HAD to see this park, I would recommend it to someone who was going to be in the city for awhile and needed a break from the traffic, noise and craziness. Its a beautiful park and there's a great outdoor shopping market nearby. The park is well maintained and a great place to spend an afternoon. Great to see, but if you're on a tight schedule, than you're not missing anything other than a nice park.
Lovely big park. The park is over the road from Dusit Thani hotel, it has lakes, recreation, Thai chi, boats and big lizards, great for a morning stroll...

A must see when in Bangkok. When you want to escape the street traders, overcrowded pavements, noise, taxis and concrete in Bangkok this is the place to go. It is probably one of the best maintained city center parks of any world capital. The park is beautifully maintained, always clean, full of ponds, lovely shady trees, huge monitor lizards and stray cays fed by the public at 5pm in the evening. It's green, shady, quiet, and has loads of exotic trees. Be aware that smoking is prohibited as is drinking alcohol. There are also a number of open air gyms where muscular Thais work up a sweat! Thoroughly recommended. Note also: the protesters have all now left and the park has been thoroughly cleaned.

Great part of the city. Definitely one of the best parks in any major Asian city. I always try and pass through at least once whenever I'm in BKK. Maybe not as great when its full of protests, but otherwise worth visiting.

Not worth it on a short trip. So, it's a nice park. If you come from a place where there's no greenery, or if you're in Bangkok for a while, you'll probably enjoy it.Otherwise it's not that special really...We walked through on a weekday, it was deserted. Probably more enjoyable on a weekend.

Lumpini Park. The park is really very nice to walk through but BUT this trip [ March 2014 ] it was full of protesters a veritable tent city there and one wonders about the hygiene there , as far as I know they are still there.If they have gone when you go it is worth walking through

A city lung. Great place to relax when the inevitable throb and pollution from dense traffic begins to be oppressive. A genuine green lung with some real surprises. A variety of wild birds live there, unexpectedly includes Roller. Very nice system of interconnected Lakes and small canals, packed with giant catfish shoals and carp. Most interesting of all are the giant water monitors. I have watched these from Myanmar to the ends of Indonesia, but they really are huge in this park in the centre of Bangkok. There are a couple of ancient males which must be 3 metres including the tail. You will see them everywhere, the population is very large. There are free live concerts, a workout session for hundreds every day at 18.00 pm (horribly fascinating and quite ridiculously western) and a whole lot of very butch guys weight lifting in different areas (I kid you not).

Being Spoiled by Protesters. This is such a beautiful park & is a great place to escape the busy Bangkok streets. . . Well, it was, This place is now a NO GO ZONE in Bangkok. The park is rapidly being spoiled by the protesters who have set up camp in the park. A ride past on the BTS into Sala Daeng station reveals the mass of plastic shelters & tents that have been erected & the rubbish strewn all around. I'm not sure if the protesters realise what they are doing to this once beautiful place or even if they care. They only seem to care about themselves.I spoke with a few Thai people about the park & they said they just don't go there any more as they don't want any trouble. . SUCH A SHAME!

Nice way to see local Thais enjoying the outdoors. There's a lot going on in this park at any time. People exercising, playing badminton, doing Tai Chi. There's a lake that you can hire boats to pedal around. Or row. Families with children might enjoy this. Some of the boats have a small roof for much-needed shade too. You can also buy food to feed the catfish and turtles at the gates on the way in for very little money.There are bathrooms and a lovely big playground. At certain times of year they offer a concert at sunset on Sundays for free. One interesting thing to see for tourists is the playing of the national anthem at 6pm. Everyone stops moving and stands still (and you would also be obliged to observe this custom). Fun, cheap afternoon out.

Westerners not allowed at present. Please be aware that the park has been taken over by a political party and is off limits to westerners.My partner and I spoke to a guy at a guarded gate and though friendly wouldn't let us in.There are hundreds if not thousands of people living in the park at present in tents,caravans,under canopies etc.Dozens of coaches surround the inner gates taking protesters to and from protest areas.We walked the full circumference of the park and saw 4 small army posts with no more than 5 soldiers there surrounded by a few sand bags.Around the Lumphini BTS area there are tons of stalls selling the usual stuff but mainly things supporting the protesters.At present our apartment us roughly 200 metres from the park and there is a constant noise of stage speakers though nothing too bad.Hopefully things will chill down as this park is a significant part of Bangkonians lives and visitors but at present it's off limits and has been for some time now.

Great place to relax in the chaos of the city. After spending a couple of days at Khao San road, and going around the temples, we decided to explore the rest of the city and stumbled across this park after taking the elevated train. It's a fantastic oasis that is definitely worth a visit. Also, there seem to be mass exercise session a few times a day; we didn't work out whether anyone could join in, but it was an interesting spectacle nevertheless.

Time to slow down. Such an attractive place to take some time out from the hustle & bustle of the city. As a European I was not use to Asian tropical heat. The park's massive lake and the shady trees are the perfect place to cool down and escape the noise and fumes of traffic. Look out for huge monitor lizards - one walked across a path as I walked around. The park is easily accessed by Skytrain Sala Daeng or MRT Silom - cross the road to the big statue of King Rama VI, which marks the parks south west corner.No smoking allowed in the park.

Nice and friendly . Had a good walk around here at 10pm one evening and watched the protesters cheering on their leaders !! Looked scary from the outside but once in and mixing with the locals they all smiled at me and one even told me that it was nice to see westerners mixing with them. Even bought a t shirt supporting them from a stall inside the park but I was told not to wear it in the street or I would be arrested. So I will just wear it around manchester instead ;/)

No matter what, but still a great place to relax.. I don't miss going to Lumpini Park when I am in Bangkok, first time I was staying near Siam Square so getting to Lumpini park was no issue as you can take a BTS (sky train) from BTS Siam Square to BTS Sala Daeng station, then just cross the road. Likewise, if you are staying around Sukhumvit area, you can also take the BTS or MRT ( Underground train to Lumpini Station). In case, you are staying around Khaosan road then its better to take a boat ride, it's the quicker and the easiest way. Go to Phra Athit pier and take a boat which is going down to the main pier which called Central Pier or Sathon Pier, get off there and take the BTS from Saphan Taksin to BTS Sala Daeng, then just cross the road and you are at Lumpini Park.Nice place to breathe while a crowded city like Bangkok. There can you see so many activities like fitness, jogging, Walking...I hope you would enjoy your time there.

Mess of Humanity. During our brief stay in Bangkok, we made a trip from Sukumvit at Soi 18 all the way across town on the BTS to Lumpini Park, specifically because someone who recently lived in Bangkok told us we'd find enormous monitor lizards running around here. Apparently the lizards were all frightened away today.The entire park was like a 1960's sit-in protest in the good old US of A. There's currently some political unrest about crooked politicians or something, and the park was jammed with tents, vendors selling T-shirts with a message, thousands of people, an enormous stage and sound system set up, etc, etc. You couldn't even see the park for the masses of humanity. No lizards - no reason to stay.
Very nice park. Lumpini Park is a great place to quiet relax of Bangkoks noise. You can take great photos there, just sit on the bench and enjoy of quiet relax, or try jogging. Great park

Despite the Tents, There is Space For Everyone. I enjoyed relaxing in Lumpini Park. There are tents that have been erected by the protestors, but I found them to only be at the Silom Road end of the park. At the other end there were lakes and chairs to relax in. I spent a good 30 minutes laying under a tree allowing leaves to fall onto my face. There are plenty of paths to stroll around and grassy areas to picnic in. The trees and marquees give great photo opportunities with the skyscrapers in the background. A row of hedges had even been carved into a row of hearts. I found Lumpini Park to be the perfect place to relax amongst the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. There are monitor lizards in the lakes as well (pic attached).
Central Park of Bangkok. This park reminded me of Central Park in New York, even though it's a bit too hot to work around even for a little while. But it is beautiful park for the city.

Normally Tranquil but now HQ of Protestors. Be aware that this normally tranquil park is currently HQ to the democracy protest movement. Still worth a look at the park and the nearby market selling goods to support the cause. As a tourist we still felt very safe when walking around it!

Camp site for protesters. Unfortunately every bit of green space has a tent pitched on it! OK if you want to see the makeshift protesters camp but don't bother if you fancied a picnic or feed the fish. No sign of the monitor lizards - they must have moved out! Having said that everyone was friendly and it did have a bit of a festival vibe.
Used to be awesome. I loved this park. Then the protesters took it over. It is now a giant camp site/trash dump. I miss my wonderful, quiet, serene little escape from Bangkok.
Away from the maddening crowd. This is an excellent place to take in the local botanic beauty and get in some good exercise away from the hustle and bustle of the city

Not the place to go at the moment. Unfortunately this is supposed to be a lovely part of Bangkok, however with the protesters having taken over the area, it is now a 'no go' area and should be avoided. Hopefully once the demonstrations are over and the park has been cleaned up it will revert to being the 'lungs' of Bangkok again
Yuck. Had a quick walkthrough, glad to get out, the squatters have moved in. There were tents everywhere, loudspeakers blairing political messages. Not relaxing at all.

DONT GO THERE!!! Protesters have taken over!. Dangerous, dirty and stinky! The protesters have been taken over the park, with their tents. Dont even go there as it seems quiet dangerous, for westerners walking through the very poor and dirty area! No police patroling inside the gates .....
Protest central / tent city. Bc of the current political tension the park is occupied by squatters and tents. Do not visit until the political situation gets better.

Nice place to walk around. I had a nice time walking around this park. Lots of locals and expats enjoying the park, and it's a nice escape from the concrete heat that suffocates the city during the day. I would recommend this place if you are taking a stroll around the Sukhumvit area, as it is a pleasant way to relax a little bit.

Lumpini is worth the stop anytime. Now, to better understand Thai politics.. While on a walkabout, I spent some time in Lumpini park. Yes, it has been transformed into a place for protesters. I found them interesting and engaging to talk with. Many spoke English well and wanted to speak with foreigners. They, and everybody in and around the park were polite and welcoming. It still is a pretty place, quiet in the morning and early afternoon. I have not made it back at night, but I would like to. Unless you speak Thai well I would avoid the evening time with small children but teens and older deserve the right to see how a political movement is really just many individuals speaking up. If you are a fearful person stay away but if you are really interested in Thailand, go, listen, learn and become more aware of what's going on.

Lovely space in a busy city. Spending a couple of days in Bangkok, Lumphini Park was one of the places I wanted to visit having read about it previously, but I had read that demonstrators had taken over one corner of the park . Getting off the BTS at Sala Daeng we walked down towards the park, where it was clear there were a number of demonstators, so we walked down Rama 4 road to the next entrance where we entered. On entering the park it became obvious that the demonstrators had taken over the entire park, however they were very friendly so we decided to take a walk around anyway.The park was lovely despite the fact that we couldn't get to many parts of it.It is definately worth a visit but I would wait until the troubles are over to enjoy it to the full.

Anti-government protesters. This is normally an oasis of peace and quiet, fresh air, in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the traffic and general craziness that is Bangkok. In February this year however, the protesters moved from blocking the streets and decamped to the park.
Not the place to go at the moment. Seems to contain a tented city at the moment - full of very peaceful looking protestors connected with the current political situation in Thailand.

Good Place for Relaxing. I visited this park just 3 - 4 hours for absorb fresh air with some exercise in Center of Bangkok.Lumpini Park is easy to go to by MRT Subway by Exit 2 and it's very good for all visitor to relax and take a rest after you shopping in whole day.Don'y miss to visit the lung of Bangkok!

An oasis and multipurpose park in busy Bangkok. I love staying around Sukhumvit area between Soi 31 and Soi 35 because Lumpini park is just close by where I can jog or do leisurely walk given the time. The park is large and well landscaped with good provisions for physical fitness activities, picnic, meditation and relaxation, biking, skateboarding, photo shoots, dating, etc. The site of the lake provides a tranquil feeling. You can enter the park for free and I think it is safe too! Use of toilet is free too:-). After jogging or doing some exercise, you can either grab something to eat or drink from vendors in front of the park or have a 5-minute walk to Emporium Mall.
large and pretty park. nice for jogging, walks and even picnics - i really enjoyed my walks here. At the time of my visit the park was taken over with protesters but they were friendly.
beautiful park, but..... .... currently, due to the demonstrations and protests, many places are occupied with tents from the protestants.

Central Park, Bangkok. We stayed at the Sofitel So, directly across the street from the Park. In fact, our room overlooked the park and we enjoyed watching from our window the various users enjoying the park- Tai Chi, yoga, bicycles, joggers, etc.We did walk through the park and enjoyed strolling the paths along the edge of the small lake.Unfortunately, we were limited from going completely through the park due to the Shutdown Bangkok protesters who had largely taken over part of the park and were camping there. While the presence of these protesters may cause some concern, there was never any trouble that we saw and did not feel endangered at anytime, even when we walked right through the protest checkpoints.At another time, when the protesters are not present, I am sure this is a lovely oasis in the chaotic city.

Relaxing and tranquil. Lumpini park is a must - just to get a breather of the the hustle and bustle of Bangkok! Go at 1pm when they play the national anthem and everyone but everyone stops and stands still to pay respect of the monarchy, all of the the people doing different classes I.e.....Tai Chi, Yoga, the dancers at the pavilion, a random group that we're doing an aerobic class and even the dogs stood still and howled!

Nice place for sports or chill. A very large park, with lakes. Locals jog here or do other sports, you can do the same or just chill on one of the benches with a book. Serene nature place in Bangkok madness.

Can Calm your nerves. If you really have time to waste in Bangkok you can visit here. People come here to relax themselves. I visited in the morning. Loads of street food can be found near the park. Entrance Free....

Park whilst occupied by protesters . It's being occupied by very very peacefully pleasent protesters I walked through blissfully ignorant and received nothing but smiles from protesters. It's something to behold. Recommended

Don't visit Lumpini whilst protests are on. We visited Lumpini Park on March 7th,but did not hang around. The park is currently a camp site for the protestors. We walked in past a number of "guards" and it became immediately apparent that we were the only non protestors there. We didn't feel at all threatened, but there is a strange atmosphere there and we didn't think it wise to go to far in. You currently can not enjoy the park or its amenities, so I'd play it safe and not run the risk of going there.

I Would Have Like To See This Park. Currently, the park has been taken over by the protestors and I was unable to visit. I hear it's lovely, but won't know because there were tents everywhere and tourists were told it wasn't safe.

beautiful place. Very nice and beautiful place , if its not so hot very nice to stroll around and enjoy the nature in the middle of Bangkok.Its surprisimg that such a big and busy city can still have such nice places.

Great for rest after exploration of the city. Lumpini Park is something like Central Park in NY, there are many differences between them of course, but still this is a peaceful area surrounded by skyscrapers. We rent a paddle boat and had a lot of fun. There are really big lizards there.

My favourite part of Bangkok. The park is full of stunning wildlife, including the much adored Water Monitor. Friendly dragons that are so used to people and tourists, that they almost pose for photos and don't seem to fussed with you walking by.

Worth a visit if you're staying in the area. Our hotel was a 15 min walk away from the park and definitely worth visiting to get away from The craziness. It's a beautiful park with a few lakes and many huge lizards which make the experience unique. It's close to the metro which is also worth using to get around the city, it's very clean, safe, quick and cheap!

Mixed emotions. i'v visited here a good number of times since my stay in Bangkok, and its hard to get the full experience. It's a beautiful area. Could easily get lost here and just sunbathe and relax. In some areas it seems to be a calm, and secluded green zone in a jungle of concrete and noise. Since the protests started back in November, this park has been taken by what can only be describes as a sea of tents, reminiscent of a festival. It's a shame really. I got talking to a Canadian gentleman whose words were "I just want my park back". Hits the nail of the head really. Come here when the protests have vanished (if they do!) and relish this beautiful zone. Until then, stay clear and save yourself from a stained first impression.
Relaxing afternoon. A big park that you can spend a whole afternoon cycling. Nice relaxing afternoon. People are nice there.

More reminiscent of a refugee camp. Have visited Lumpini Park in the past when is was free of protesters and found it to be a calm oasis in a sea of concrete and glass, and well worth a visit. But our latest visit was more reminiscent of a refugee camp. Anti-government protesters have literally pitched thousands of one-man tents all over the park together with washing lines, portable toilets and stalls selling mostly clothing. There are also loud speakers blurting out speeches and music non-stop (I wouldn’t recommend staying in any nearby hotels). Outside the main gates are larger tents giving away free food and drinks. However, having said all that I must say there was no sense of menace, and we felt completely safe. The protesters were all smiles and very friendly. All they seemed to have done is block off nearby streets and then set up stalls to sell a variety of items mostly reflecting their cause. Would recommend a visit to the park once the protesters have dispersed.
Go to meet peaceful rioters or skip it. It's a park, a green spot surrounded by skycrapers, but apart from a walk during the day or cruising at night, there is little interest for a foreign tourist

Over ran by protesters. The park's lakes and playgrounds make it a lovely way to while away the hours with the little ones. Until of course we arrive and notice that the gates have been boarded up and the park is now a makeshift camp for anti-government protesters. Why didn't any I one post this earlier? They look like they're settling in for the long haul.

A treasure when you need a break from the city. I spent a few hours just wandering around this oasis. The city can really get to you if you aren't used to big bustling cities, and I was in need for some nature. Lumpini park provided that. It was wonderful just watching families come here to walk, workout, and take in a little bit of nature. I wouldn't visit this place, unless you really need a break from the normal sites and the city. I probably would have not visited if I was not staying in Bangkok for over a week.

Great place to hide away from the rush of the city.. Biggest park in Bangkok contains small lakes and huge palm trees. Great place for a morning run or to spend a peaceful afternoon. Easy to get there by the MRT (Lumpinee station)

Great Getaway in Bangkok. A nice respite from the hustle & bustle of the city, while being right in the city. A great place to take a break or to get some exercise. Food vendors just outside were also delicious.

Market & Food. There is so much to do and see here. The market is filled with all sort of items only found in Thailand. You have to bargain hard to bing the price down, although many have set prices.The variety would keep you on your feet walking all day long. Wear comfortable shoes.
Peaceful Park. Big park to escape the hussel and bussel watch locals doing Tai Chi or go for a jog, can be busy but thats ok.

Great place to walk, run, exercise and enjoy local culture.. Great place to take in during the early morning and exercise while enjoying some local cultural activities from young and old. The park is larger than you observe and paths and walk ways go on and on. Young and old alike out to enjoy the morning before the heat builds Walk, jog, run and observe. worth the effort....

Beautiful Park. We did not expect to find such a place in such a busy city in Bangkok, it is really a beautiful and peaceful area, there is a lake were you can rent paddle boats and walking around the park is also great. Just a good place to spend a day and relax.

A green place in a crowded city. The park is clean, safe and a tranquil place to walk or just sit and relax. It is easy to access -- and just as easy to leave. No hassles. It is also adjacent to some great "off the radar" places to have a local meal.

Lumpini Park. Lumpini Park is a nice patch of greenery in central Bangkok that allows one to temporarily escape the mad crush of people and vehicles in Bangkok. It actually was right below of the the hotels in which we stayed while in Bangkok, and we had ringside views of the political rallies taking place to protest corruption in government.
a must. a lovely park, watch out for the giant lizzards that live in the water! A nice place to sit and relax. be aware there was a lot of protestors camped in the park when we visited it.

Anyone for a big day out?. This place is huge and there are lots of different areas to explore, unfortunately when I was there, Bangkok was having it's demonstrations and Lumpini Park is where they gathered. A lot of people had little tents set up and they were there overnight, so it wasn't the great place I was hoping for. Better luck next time.

Protests ruined my experience. Because I was there while the Bangkok shutdown/Protests were happening, the park was unfortunately taken over by protesters who had camped out and made tents all over the park, so when I went there, all I saw was tents and people sitting around. Despite that I still could see that there was some beauty about this park, its just a shame that I couldn't see its full beauty.

Tranquility amidst the chaos of Bangkok!!. Ok ok we admit it... The main reason why we visited here was to see the famous monitor lizards, and we weren't disappointed!!Apart from the lizards the park was a lovely surprise... Peaceful, laid back, wonderfully kept. We hired pedal boats and enjoyed the views of Bangkoks sky scrapers emerging from the greenery and lakes of the park.We came here twice in the end to enjoy the relaxed atmosphere. If you have a spare hour, it's definitely worth a stop.

Very green. This park was near to my hotel. I was not able to visit the park the first couple days due to the Bangkok Shutdown that occurred during my visit. Demonstrators were protesting in the streets. I had no problems though. It re-opened in a couple days and I went for a walk and watched 50 Thai people doing Thai Chi. So amazing.

Good park........ Enjoy a lot here with my friends any weekend near lumphini MRT station, Enjoy a lot here with my friends any weekend near lumphini MRT station,Enjoy a lot here with my friends any weekend near lumphini MRT station,Enjoy a lot here with my friends any weekend near lumphini MRT station,Enjoy a lot here with my friends any weekend near lumphini MRT station,Enjoy a lot here with my friends any weekend near lumphini MRT station,Enjoy a lot here with my friends any weekend near lumphini MRT station,

Relaxing . If you are staying in Bangkok for more than a week and want to stretch up your muscles a bit. This is the place where you can jog around and utilize their equipments for doing some stretching. You can do picnics here just bring your own mat. The place is also clean. And they provide a bathroom for those who want to shower after sweating.

Great place to wander and people watch. Great open space to wander around and people watch, its in the heart of the city and hosts regular free events at weekends. Busy all day from early morning Chinese fitness exercises to evening night joggers.

Amazing lizards!. Spent a Sunday morning strolling through the park. Took loads of photographs. One of the reasons for visiting the park was to see the lizards! Not disappointed! Once we got into the main park we saw quite a few lying in the sun minding their own business. Great time to depend a few hours.

Nice walk/run. Another oasis of green space in the Big Mango. Much welcomed. I especially like it when there are events at this park. The greenery with the event is entertaining in and of itself. Take a stroll or a job and take in the green aesthetics.
Great place to escape the city. Excellent place in Bangkok for a run or leisurely walk. Scenic and always fun to watch the monitor lizards!
Pretty. A great place to run in the early morning - or to burn off some excess energy with your kids. Take a camera and do some people spotting too!

Beautiful and peaceful.. I enjoyed an afternoon walk through the park while on my trip. It's massive in size and very beautiful and tranquil. Reminded me a lot of Central Park and Yoyogi Park. A quiet green space in a large city to relax in.
Anti-govt demonstrations!. The anti-government demonstrations were peaceful and it was a carnival at night with great T-shirts to remember the date of the demonstrations.

Tranquility in a frenetic city. Definitely a place to relax, chill and unwind! They have large lakes, lots of trees, and a variety of smaller flowering plants. And despite being slap bang in the middle of Bangkok, Lumpini Park is an amazingly tranquil relaxing area. There are many benches to sit on, there's even a small amphitheatre where you can watch students rehearsing their performances. And if you're observant you'll find some shy but rather intimidating water monitor lizards! Don't worry, they keep clear of people, and it's a carefully planned task to approach them for close-up photos.Generally, I'd recommend spending a few hours, maybe a morning or an afternoon, here.

Nice Park with lizards. you have to cross a busy street to get to the park from the MRT but once there its a pretty cool park, huge trees, lizards sunbathing, we chased a few. nice to spend an hour or so walking around to get away from the smell and hustle of bangkok.

Full of protesters at the moment. Heard all the talk about "shutting down" the city for the political protests but it was nothing big. The park was full of people, but I even went to the BNH clinic for a Japanese encephalitis shot and the street was open. Didn't really see the park much
gr8 value hotel. AETAS is the best hotel to stay in bangkok and good service ,rooms,staff and breakfast..perfecto.. dont forget to stay in AETAS LUMPINI when you are here in Bangkok
Great place for a walk/run near Central World hotels. This hotel is located about .5 miles from Central World shopping. If you are staying nearby and enjoy running or walking it is a great place!

Well worth a stroll - lovely park in the heart of the city. Our hotel was near the park (in Silom) and it is lovely place to spend some time in BKK - nicely landscaped and set out, lots of paths and ponds, even paddle boats you can hire (though we didn't). On Sunday there were also lots of locals exercising (with some noisy outdoor classes going on) which was fun, but it was really quiet during the week and worth a visit anytime especially as a break from the traffic and noise. A good place for a picnic and to take children too.

A true city park, used by everyone. This is a terrific green space, used by local people of all ages as well as tourists. It's open from very early in the morning - people running, exercising, doing Tai Chi, eating breakfast or just wandering. Lots to do and see - eating places and restful spaces, playgrounds, walks, a small lake with paddle boats in the shape of swans, interesting buildings/pagodas - I even spied a huge water dragon. A green oasis in a very bustling city.

Big park to enjoy. Lumpini park is a very big park for anyone to explore. It has lots of greenery and different statues with proper details on it. It’s a nice place to spend time with family and friends. It has various gates through which you can enter. The best option for me was the gate near the lumpini MRT. A very nice park

Nice retreat from the hustle of the business center. The park is a nice spot for a retreat from the main business centre and it's huge roads. Lumpini Park is quite big and really well looked after. Cycling is allowed inside and you can surround the inner circle or even drive the island. Bring food and time if you want to relax on the benches right next to the water or just sitting on the grass.

Green space and in manic city. Nice green space with lakes in the city, worth a visit just to escape the mayhem if Bangkok. The day I went it was surprisingly quite.Smokers be warned - there is no smoking allowed in the park.

This park is amazing! (if you like giant lizards). This park is very nice and similar to most other large city parks but it has a cool twist. It is completely full of water monitor lizards, from little baby monitors climbing through the sewer grates to enormous adults several meters long. The park is like an open air zoo exhibit that you can walk through. On the other hand, if you are nervous of water monitors this park should probably be avoided...
Lovely quiet park. Was very closed to our hotel. Kids played on the playground. Saw huge water dragons. Hired the paddle boats for a little bit of fun for the Kids.
Great Place To Chill. This is an awesome place in the heart of an extraordinary city. Lots of people use this Park for practicing sport, training etc.
Nice Park. A very nice park. It's best to get there early to see the Fitness Brigade !! If your feeling energetic you can join in !!
Oasis in the city. Lumpini is easy to get to and is a real escape from the Bangkok mayhem. There are rarely many people here, a lovely lake and always space to sit alone and contemplate.
Good for a run around with the kids. Good spot for the kids to run around and have a break from looking at temples etc There is a boating lake, play area and food spots outside.

Great place to run or chill. Any green spaces in big cities are a draw card for me. I was staying a short walk from here and enjoyed a morning run. The outside track (with the yellow line) is exactly 2.5kms which makes it convenient to keep track. Plenty of venders to buy water from are both in and outside the gates.
Central Park Bangkok. Biggest park in central bangkok and a good place for walking or exercise, have playground and boat for rent......

Just another city park. Lumpini Park is a nice large park in the city to get away from the dirt and grim of the streets, it's worth having a walk through to relax and take 5 if you have the time. But at the end of the day it's just another city park, if you live in a city you may appreciate it more but if you live out of the city in the country it probably won't seem to special.

Beautiful and peaceful. Decided to take a stroll on Lumpini park after seeing it the previous day from the BTS skytrain. It is huge and has some small lakes or ponds, I even saw a few massive monitor lizards kicking about, some birds and turtles. A stunning and peaceful place. Also very good for jogging and biking, or to rent a small boat.
Amazing Space in BKK. Huge park….great for running and walking. Take a boat on the lake and feed the fish….you will also see turtles and lizards/geckos.

Peaceful in the heart of a busy city!. It definitely feels good to have a break in Lumpini park after roaming around in busy Bangkok! The place is clean and big enough to have a nice walk!Do look for the monitor lizards who roam around freely.Do check tai chi chuan or aerobic classes (depending on your visit time), even if you don't join it is always nice to see part of it!And if you are there for the King's song (8 am, 6 pm) you will see the full crowd freezing in a minute, quite an amazing and strange view for a foreigner!

ok for a walk. the park is large and has a few different ponds and grassy areas. ok for a walk but the sewerage smell kept wafting over us which was a put of a put off. but it's a nice green space in the middle of the city.

good place for the family. i went here with a friend walking about... with the lake where you can rent boats and shady areas where you can have lunch, people jogging around, dancing, playing etc, there's even a swimming pool and public toilets. Its such a peaceful place knowingly that it is located in one of the noisiest areas of Bangkok. The place is safe and clean and good for the whole family!
Lumpini park. I like this park because its like green in the city. You can jog around or simply enjoy nature. Very relaxing.

Lungs of the city. Watch out for water monitor lizards, swimming among the swan paddle boats. Late in the afternoon, relax on a park bench with an icecream and watch the grimmaces on the faces of the joggers.
We like this park. You can feed fishes (catfishes) in a lake or get a boat for 80B per 1 hour. It is closed after 8-9 p.m.

Beautiful oasis. Quiet in the afternoon to sit in the sun, heaving on the saturday morning where it felt like every resident on Bangkok had descended on the park to run, have breakfast, do tai chi or just meet friends. Lovely atmosphere and beautiful first thing in the morning with the sun shining on the lakes.
Nice park. There are quit a few parks in Bangkok but this is one of the better ones. Very spacious so you can always find a good spot to sit and relax.
Nice oasis in heart of city. Great place to spend some time . Very nice park . Very clean and pleasant. lots of monitor lizards too watch

Lovely Park in a Super City. Enjoyed a lovely walk around the park on a sunny day in Bangkok. Lots of grass and areas for children to play. Wish I had had my trainers with me as there is a great jogging and cycling path around it. Could have spent all day relaxing in the park with a picnic. Limited snacks available. Easy walk from Central shopping area.

A nice quite spot in busy Bangkok. Awesome resting place for a quiet afternoon.In the weekend a lot of locals come to the park to play games and lay on the grass.The monitor lizards are also pretty cool and impressive.
Relaxed. Great place to escape the hustle and bustle of Bangkok City for a while, enjoy a stroll or a picnic whilst taking in the scents of the beautiful flowers on the breeze.

Small dinosaurs run amuck!!. You have to pay for toilet paper in the bathrooms - take change
The giant monitor lizards are everywhere along the banks of the river, scared the bejesus out of us, especially since they look like Komodo dragons (almost identical). Park is nice, clean but not easy to get a taxi or tuk tuk from

The green lung of Bangkok. We stayed only a few blocks from the park and used it several times during our stay. Firstly it is a place where you can escape the fuzz of the city. Secondly it is a great place to take a stroll or run some laps. It is 2,5km around the park and plenty people jogging. When the sun sets there is light in the park and there are public workout equipment and playgrounds in the parks. At some times there's also public aerobic sessions in the park. At 8am and 6pm they play the national anthem over the speakers and everyone stands still - a very interesting and different experience. PS. Watch out for the varans. They look like alligators but are supposedly very friendly :)

Walk here!. a walk through this park in the evening is a must. Lovely park, good place to observe the BGK culture, even the lake is stunning and gives a nice outlook and break from bustling city. Also, some hotties can be seen in the Muscle area of the park (a free weight gym) so if some eye candy is what you looking for, go here :)
Beautiful. We drove by Lumpini Park in the night and it looked pretty appealing, well lit and beautiful. Pity we did not stop could not detour

A beautiful and tranquil haven. When ever I am in Bangkok for more than a day or two, I always take time out to go for a walk (usually early morning) through Lumphini Park. It's great place to just relax and chill out from the madness of the city. It's also a great place for a picnic (buy some street food from outside and sit down under a tree or in one of the many picnic shelters).

Welcome respite, bike rental would enhance. This lovely park sits between Rachadamri and Sala Daeng on the BTS line and between Silom and Lumphini on the MRT line. What a serene, beautiful place to recharge batteries in the heart of the city. Experience would be improved if they had rental bikes within walking distance so the entire park could easily be visited. There are city-share bikes close by, but as we have noticed in other large cities (eg, Rome) you need a special card to access them - not for tourists.

Visit the park early morning. Our hotel was located near the parc, so it was perfect for a morning run. At around 8:00 am I found the park crowded with locals, often families, having some sort of huge breakfast picnic (although it smelled more like lunch or diner). There was a very nice and bliss atmosphere this early with people enjoying themselves, eating, doing sport or just chatting. If you go on the island in the middle of the lake you will find the komodos --- those big lizards. Don't forget your camera :) They walk around freely.

Must See City Park. Lumpini Park is one of the greatest inner city parks in the world. Don't get pick pocketed and this will be an amazing experience of people watching and Thai Culture and beautiful gardens! Please GO. I recommend going in the morning before 9 AM.
Nice big park. A nice big park to get some fresh air and respite from all the concrete and smoke everywhere around the city.
AMAZING!. Lumpini park is amazing. A must see. I bring the kids here all the time and they love it and love the parks.

Good place to Jog. Nothing much to offer. Locals jog within the area at night or early in the morning. There is also an outdoor gym or workout area.
Some performances like play and mini concerts are held but in local language.

A beautiful oasis in the City. This is a beautiful park in a busy city. It was a great oasis of peace and quiet, yet right in the city. There are families hanging out, people playing games and such. It is great place for a stroll and to relax.

Beautiful Park. This is a beautiful Park in Bangkok centre, where you can run from the hustle and bustle of the city. This is tranquil and peaceful and green. Perfect for a picnic or if you simply want to "chill" in a nice spot. I would recommend this as a safe haven from the rush.Just be warned, it is quite a steep walk from there to the main centre(about 1km) and in the heat and humidity of Bangkok, this becomes a bit exhausting, so rather take taxi or Tuk Tuk to get there and back..
What a Nice Park!. if you need an oasis from the bustle of Bangkok, Lumpini Park is the place. It's a large, beautiful park right in the middle of an urban megalopolis.

Beautiful park. We took an early morning stroll around 6am to explore this oasis. We were surprised at all the different people inviting us to join their jogging-crew or just simply saying hello. We attended a lesson of t´ai chi and this old man was so excited that we joined in so he became our personal instructor. Furthermore we were invited to a small tea-party with what seemed to be the two oldest men in the park. All in all quite an experience, try it out! The surroundings will give you a break from the humid and hot streets of Bangkok.
An Oasis. A pleasant place to escape the bustle of the city. It is surprisingly large considering it's location. The only downside is the foodcourt was closed during the lunchtime period.

Big park. I love this park most of all. While nearly all of the parks in Bangkok include exercise equipment and walking/jogging trails, Lumphini has a few locations around the park where this is found. There is Tai Chi in the early morning for those who start their day quite early and various aerobic or dance workouts throughout the day. You can also just walk around and enjoy the many different trees and flowers. Its very beautiful and you feel like you are outside of Bangkok. Maybe you will even make friends with a turtle...or a giant lizard!

Beautiful Place. My dear friend and I decided to go to Lumpini Park for the Bangkok Street Show 2013. What a great idea, the park itself is beautiful and allows a good view of some of Bangkok's skyline. We also spotted some big lizards sunbathing while boating around the paddle boating. Street food nearby is also excellent. We just loved it.

What's random little park... I loved this park. On arrival I thought it was going to be a bit if a disappointment but I'd got it all wrong.It's not what you'd expect when your from the UK. But seeing lizzards swimming down the river and turtles being fed by the locals is an experience.Try it out. It's not the prettiest park but it's different and worth checking out.
Beautiful running park. For runners, including this as part of your itinerary when in Bangkok is a must. Perhaps the best running park I have been to.

Jogging Place. Love to jog here at morning or afternoon! Lots of variant activities here like yoga etc.
The air is nice here and also the ambience.
At night you can see some lover birds around this Park :)

Big Green Space in Bangkok, but.... Lumpini Park is a nice reprieve from the spawling urban jungle of Bangkok, but due to the climate, it isn't lush, it isn't that inviting, and it could use some more fauna and perhaps some activities. They do have monitor lizards to entertain you, a peaceful pond to contemplate around, and a pathway to jog on which is nice along with some good views of the Bangkok skyline. Again, big green space in Bangkok is incredibly welcome, but coming from the west, you may be in for a bit of a letdown from this park.

Monitor Lizards spotted. I had read about these large lizards and thought it would be cool to find them at the park and we did. We got off the BTS and had a bit of a hair raising time crossing the non- traffic lighted intersection crossing but the trick is to walk calmly across when there is a break in traffic., probably easier to walk up the road a wee bit and cross when there is only one way traffic to deal with. Took us a while to see our first lizard but as we walked around the paddle boating lake we saw much larger ones in pairs just hanging around sun bathing around the lake edge. Lots of quiet spaces but the park could be prettied up with more flowering plants and beds I reckon. A childrens playground is also there but I believe the place is most popular with locals early moring for exercise and in weekends. Definitely worth going to see these monitor lizards; also spotted a turtle, white cranes, large black noisy crows, pretty butterfly. We did this visit as a way to fill in about an hour of time on the way to do another activity, visited about 11.30 am, not too hot, lots of shady trees.

when you need to make a break in your sightsseing. in the heart of BKK, this park is very quiet and peaceful; you could easily walk around the small lacs, land on the grass, and even watch out the famous "warrants of Comodo"!!!

nice place to excercise. on vacation and enjoyed the view and the weather. yes hot but no pain no gain. went back again the next day and met some cool people from New Zeeland.. Will go back soon to work out.
Beautiful. This is an excellent park to walk and get away from the hustle and bustle of BKK. Very beautiful and large area. Great for family and co workers

Nothing out of the ordinary. I have been to many places and many parks, and can say I was not impressed by any means. Yes, it is green, but park is supposed to be. It was quiet, true, but I was by no means impressed by either its size not its structure. Overall, avoid, unless you have absolutely nothing else to do!

Nice Park. The park is lovely with a lot of space and a nicely sized lake. However, we were not awed by it. After viewing the gorgeously maintained and exotic parks in Hong Kong, this left us wanting.

Lush, pristine, a respite from the bustling city. This green haven is a great escape for anyone overwhelmed by the madness of Bangkok. Rent a boat and paddle the lake there for a bit. Easily reached by Skytrain or MRT.

A different experience. I have never seen a monitor lizard up close and on the loose, and never thought that they are actually safe. It's such a great experience that animals and humans can enjoy nature without either being a threat to each other. We had a really good time here, especially the kids who were very amused and marvelled at the different animals that they don't usually see in the zoo. I guess it comes with the climate, and so it was really a good decision for us to come over to Bangkok and experience such exquisite experience first hand. For those in Thailand, I guess this is a natural thing for them, but truly fascinating for us!

Relaxing. Nice place to relax after hot and busy Bangkok. Kids playgrounds and lake with waterdragons and turtles are nice and relaxing. Have food before you go, we went on Sunday noon hungry and there is no foodcourt as mentioned on map.

Just another ordinary park in Bangkok. Went there recently because of Bangkok Street Carnival over the weekends-Buskers performing from afternoon till night. Also been there 2 years ago during the flood for Loy Kratong since they are not allow to use Chao Phraya River for the celebration. It is huge park. Not much to see. Quiet if no activities are held there. Near BTS Sala Daeng. Walking distance to Patpong.
Great place to escape for a bit of peace. Lumpini park is a great place go spend a few hours, it's nice and tranquil. Hardly anyone there so there's plenty of places to go for a picnic etc
well kept. A nice place to stroll around if you have the time to spare, surprisingly quiet , given the location, the grounds are clean and well kept
Skip it. It's just a park, nothing special unless u enjoy seeing fifty half starved dogs running around a brown polluted lake. Trust me, u didn't come to bangkok for this

Great green area in Bangkok. We came here to go for walk in the morning. It was totally lovely to have this park in a noizy city like Bangkok. There's lots of flowers, trees, small lakes, birds, butterflies,...in a well design green space. Being here in a fresh and nice atmosphere, looking people doing exercises around in Bangkok is quite an unexpected experience.
Bangkok's Central Park. Went there to take a stroll on Sunday morning. Nice big place to jog around, and watch the local to their exercise. Great place to take your children to play.

Love the Greenery. Enjoyed my run once again at the park. 2.6KM each round and do about 3 to get about 7.8KM.People are friendly and no aggressive running. Beautiful sculptures around the park. No cyclist allowed till after 10am.Guards around the park provides good security. If you are adventurous, go and find the food court near entrance 3 and you can try the local chinese breakfast. Even a birds nest.
A little piece of paradise in central Bangkok. A great place to exercise or just relax and watch the world go by.The night bazaar is also a must do for first-time visitors to this wonderful city.

Need to chill out in Bangkok?. When in Bangkok visit this park, it is walking distance from the noise and hustle and bustle of the city but feels like a million years away. You can easily find a nice shaded place to sit relax, chill out and let the world pass you bye. It is ideal for a few hours of doing nothing, and then you feel like you are ready to tackle the real world again.
Massive park. A very huge park where one can take a leisure long walks..in the heart of the city close to the BTS.

Great urban green space. Lumphini Park is a large open green space in the middle of hectic Bangkok. The park hosts a variety of festivals and events such as Loi Krathong and the Bangkok Street Show, but it's also perfect to just explore on a sunny day. I enjoy finding a shady spot to relax and read a book and feel like I'm not in the middle of an expansive urban area!

Peace & calm in busy city. Lovel to walk about early in the morning, calm - great places to sit and watch the locals enjoy the outdoors. Great place to watch the bustle from the calmness of a beautiful park. Miss the nightmarket here!

GIANT LIZARD. Lumpini is a large, beautiful, quirky park in central Bangkok. See local tai chi groups, utilitarian outdoor public weightlifting facilities, big ugly crows and terrifying giant lizards, including one who I am convinced is the King of all lizards.

Nice views, activities,. The park is great for walking, running, biking, or doing a little bit of group aerobic exercise. There are animals, ponds, city views, and places to eat. There are some good activities for the kids, but I enjoyed running there and finding a nice place near the pond to sit and read my book. One thing that no one seems to believe: there are giant lizards in the park. I mean like huge, komodo dragon lizards or something. I was walking along the side of the pond and saw something big swishing through the water. As it got closer to shore, I saw that it was a rather large (like four foot) lizard. Yeah, that was pretty strange. Anyway, great park!

Difficult to find an entrance, but once you're in its beautiful.. We looked for about 10 minutes around the park to try and find an entrance and then the one we found lead into a car park then into the park, but once we were in and looking at the greenery it was rather beautiful. Butterflies everywhere, and lots of lovely trees. the lakes are great for going on a quick pedalow and we saw so many monitor lizards it was unreal! beautiful park with a wonderful view of the city behind it, its like Bangkok's central park! Go and relax at this lovely park as a break form the madness of the city.

my favourite place in Bangkok. If you want to go for a run, spend some time watching turtles and varans or just play with fishes by throwing some bread into the water - Lumphini Park is the place to be.Very clean, lots of beverage station, a good Thai original "food plaza" and lots of green! For runners and bikers you will find various runnings/driving tracks.

A green space in the heart of Bangkok. Parks are important particularly in busy cities like Bangkok.Lumpini Park is a pleasant green space with lakes and walkways just perfect for relaxing at the end of the day or for an early start in the morning.Nothing much else to appeal except for the large water monitors (lizards) that are often seen wandering around.

Great place to relax from the hussle. Early morning joggers, Thai Chi and yoga classes take over many parts of the park. Well laid out with some ponds of water with turtles and fish in them. Large lizards wandering about.

A gift to the Thai people. Lumphini Park is a wonderful example of why parks are so important to world cities. A late afternoon/early evening stroll is a great way to wind up a stay in Bangkok. Better still stay at the Dusit next door and go for a 6am walk, just so much to see and appreciate

a sort of park. for a semi-greenish space in Bangkok its pretty refreshing. Oh and if you make it right through to the other side and you find yourself in the school park there is the most perfect of lawn. Under closer inspection it is fake turf and be cautioned as to the discharge of static electricity you will experience the next moment you meet metal.

More than trees, plants and flowers. We went to see the park because of good recommandations. Sitting down to look at the trees, the water, the surrounding skyscrapers and relax my husband told me - it is some animals here coming from the sewer. Oh - how big are they? He streched out his arms. No, you are joking with me. After that I was continually looking for these animals in the water. And suddenly as we passed a bridge I saw a little head in a pipe. We stopped and starred - a lizard was moving out in slow motion and jumped into the water. He ( I'm sure it was a male) was so big as my husband had told me and so fat that his belly looked like a balloon. After a little swimming tour he returned to his tube. Very special and exciting to see an animal like this in the middle of a big city.

A peaceful place in busy town. Not really the place where you would like to go if you are short of time. However i wd recommend it if you want some time to just relax and be at peace, away from all the busy schedules. Lots of flowers and greenery and water bodies.

Bangkok's version of Central Park. Absolutely gorgeous, peaceful park in the heart of hectic Bangkok.Lots of lush greenery and flowers, a large pond and bridges. It's a great place to people watch and take photos. I happened to be there on a day when Thai marine corps marching band were practising. It then started raining buckets, but everyone stayed to watch the performance - its was very impressive.Closest station to the main entrance is Silom BTS.

Free Park In The Center Of Bangkok. There's no fee at all when you enter this park. You can find family, people jogging inside of the park there will also be pedalo for hire here. Personally I think this is a nice park to jog.Surrounding the park during night time they will change into hawker center in front of the park gate. You can sit here and just watch the duck swimming here and there. Park can be reach using BTS and they also provide parking lot hereCheers. . .

Nice, vast park. Some interesting features. Great to walk around for an hour or so. Loved watching the dogs and water monitors wandering about. Few interesting bits to stop and chill for. Worth a visit.

Beautiful park. Really nice park too walk around....approx 2.8 km long, really green, and heaps to see. Would be nice to bike ride around, heaps of people using the park, right in the of middle of Bangkok. Really pretty...Bangkok's version of new yorks Central Park. Highly recommend.

A green and calm place in the middle of Bangkok. I spent there some 4hours, in a day of transit in Bangkok.It's calm and fresher than the city, you can walk, ride bicycle and seat on the grass, under the trees to read.But I read in some guidebook that "it was like going outside Bangkok"...Not really! Don't expect more than a big city-park!

Rain or shine - this park has something for everyone!. In 2009 I was at Lumphini park in a downpour of rain. It was FANTASTIC. We saw dozens of large monitors (lizards - related to Komodo dragons) and we thought maybe that was the only time they came out. However, yesterday (Nov 29), it was hot and sunny and we saw over 50. This time - lots of little ones were out and about. We didn't see nearly as many very large ones (7+ feet long). I think we saw only 3 or 4 really large monitors. Most were 2-4 feet. And, most are willing to let you get a shot or two before they start to cruise away. One came pretty close to me (which is rare that they walk to you). Ultimately, rain or shine, this park is a must. Just bring an umbrella for the rain and you can stay for hours...This is a great park. Wonderful just to wander about but phenomenal if you want to see lots of wild animals in an interesting/natural setting. We saw lots of monitors, turtles, and birds: heron, egrets, mocking birds, and a kingfisher. It was spectacular. Every time we come to Bangkok we try to visit this park. Definitely a must see for a relaxing and interesting day.

Excellent photowalk time. We had an excellent photowalk time at Lumpini Park last week and we enjoyed it very much.
